What is UFW? # UFW stands for Uncomplicated Firewall and is cli app that makes it easier to configure iptables.
Why use it? # Well, having a good firewall setup is a must in order to have good security on any system. And UFW just so happens to be easy to configure and is an awesome firewall this is why I have chosen it for this guide. Note there many other firewalls with one of them being firewalld.
Installing UFW # Ubuntu/Debian. # sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y sudo install ufw -y Although if you are on Ubuntu, UFW may already be installed.
Arch # sudo pacman --noconfirm -Syu sudo pacman --needed --noconfirm -S ufw Fedora # NOTE: By default Fedora uses firewalld so you can use the following commands to remove it if you wish. I AM NOT LIABLE FOR ANYONE BREAKING THEIR SYSTEM!.
sudo systemctl disable firewalld.service --now sudo dnf remove firewalld -y Now you can install UFW
sudo dnf upgrade -y sudo dnf install ufw Setting Default Policys # With UFW you can set default policys and then set specific rules for example allowing a certain port.
sudo ufw default deny incoming sudo ufw default allow outgoing This will by default deny incoming requests and allow outgoing requests, this is generally good practice.
Enabling and Disabling ports # Enabling # I use hugo to make this website, and to use the hugo server I have to enable port 1313. To do this the command is.
sudo ufw allow 1313 Disabling # Then to disable this port type.
sudo ufw deny 1313 In Conclusion # Hopefully this article has given you a good base level of knowledge on how to use UFW. You can now secure your system with a firewall. Hope you found this article useful.
title: A guide to UFW

Written in Bash # Because I am not programmer but love and use Linux everyday, my knowledge of Bash scripting has become quite good. This is why I have chosen to write this app in my love language bash. I do have quite a good knowledge of Python, but Bash still seemed like the right choice here.
What does Bashfetch do? # Bashfetch, grabs basic system information just like neofetch. But it is quicker than neofetch as it only prints out one ascii logo and not a different one depending on the distro. It also allows you to customize the output without the config file and with an interactive menu written in bash by typing.
bashfetch --config Although I am still Developing this CLI app so if you use it don’t expect it to work flawlessly. Check it out # You can check it out with the link above. Hope you like it.
